Dialogue: Sure you are. You're The Shooter's woman.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Right. And maybe I'll go on being The Shooter's Woman, even after you and I have had our little romp. What do you think about that?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: First place, Old Shooter'll come barging through that door any minute. He said they were winding it up.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: No barging. He doesn't have his key with him.  So we can treat ourselves to a little sample of things to come.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Also it don't mean anything to you, you're Christian's friend?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Honey, she lost her franchise the minute she got on that bus. You know that.  I have a shaky sense of security, Kid. Don't make me feel unwanted.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: No good?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You know damn well how good it was. Where's a pack of cards?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: What do we need cards for?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Gin or casino, you name it. All I know is we're switching to another indoor sport.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Lady Fingers'll want to come, I bet, and she's right on the edge of her stake. She could spell me dealing.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure. Haven't seen the dear old bitch in fifteen years.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Well, that's it, then. Monday night, Room Three-Eleven at the Dorset Hotel. And may the best man win.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Yes, that's how it usually comes out in the long run. You think this boy is going to give me trouble, Shooter?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Yeah, he's going to give you trouble.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: I don't want it to be one of those marathon games. Not any more.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Like the session with The Portugee at Jolly's in Omaha. Remember?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure. Longest game I ever played though, I was a kid on my way to the Klondike gold rush. At Soapy Smith's in Skagway. Four nights and three days.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You win?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Depends how you look at it. When we wound up, the Yukon River had frozen over and you couldn't get through to Dawson City till the following June. Made myself a Hundred and fifty bucks and missed the gold rush.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You been around a long time.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: That is undeniably true. But it doesn't mean I'm ready to retire. How old is this boy of yours?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Twenty-six, twenty-eight, something like that.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Well, now, makes me feel a whole lot better, knowing that. I was thirty- six when I sliced up Eddie the Dude. This Kid of yours is just going to have to wait a few years.

Speaker: felix
Dialogue: Excuse me, Mr. Shooter, sir, but Mr. Schlaegel asked me to remind you how eager he was to see you.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I ought to call my woman.

Speaker: felix
Dialogue: Yes, of course. They always like to know it if you're going to be late for supper.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Still building eights.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thanks for putting it together for me.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: It's not my game.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Want to know what is?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Hello -- Oh, hi, sugar -- why not?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: What's the switch?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Whose idea was that?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: He's not coming home now.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Whatever you say, Shooter man.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Explain to The Kid, will you?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: He'll understand.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Tell him they decided to play a little longer, and I'll call him at his place later when the game's over... Right. Goodbye, honey.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Listen, Melba --

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I have to tell you first. You're sitting down with Lancey next Monday night.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I wish it was sooner. I wish it was tomorrow.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Shooter'll give you all the details later.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I don't like waiting that long.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Let's not kick a gift horse in the teeth, sugar. We've got this time together. Let's try to "fill each unforgiving minute with sixty seconds worth of distance run."

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Listen, what I was going to say before, I don't want you to think I'm being some kind of jerk or I don't feel you'd be great to sack up with.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Then let's cut the filibuster.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I've made dolls that were friends of mine's wives. I figured if they were willing, they were doing it to their husbands, I wasn't.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Of course. Any other attitude, you're degrading the woman. You're not treating her as a person with a mind of her own, but as somebody's property.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Only thing is, it's different with The Shooter than anybody else. He's so straight, I got the obligation to be straighter with him than other people. So do you. On account of we both owe him plenty.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I thought we just agreed that what you and I did was strictly between us.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Can't be.  Shooter's the closest thing to family I got. It's almost like he was my old man. Don't you see how that's got a bearing on us?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Sure, it means I'm your mother.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Shooter -- very generous of you to come on such short notice. Rosanna you know, and I think you've met my daughter June.  No point introducing you to William the Fourth. He has a bad memory for names.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Mrs. Schlaegel. How are you, June. What's it all about, Bill?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Little something I'd like to sound you out on. But the least I can do is offer you a drink.

Speaker: rosanna
Dialogue: Like me to fix it, love?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Wonderful. Why don't you do a batch of your Bloody Marys? If that's okay with you, Shooter?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Great. Whatever.

Speaker: rosanna
Dialogue: Just don't let it get wet again.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I've been quite busy on the telephone since I last saw you. There's a lot of interest all over the country in this game with Lancey and The Kid.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Betting interest?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Jack Doyle in New York is giving twelve to five on Lancey. Same odds in Reno. I've taken fifty thousand of it so far.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Fifty thousand!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I'll probably go for more but I didn't want to rock the odds.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I knew you liked The Kid's style but why you going in so deep?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Two reasons. First, I want to see that smug old bastard gutted worse than he gutted me. Second, as long as that's going to happen, I don't see why I shouldn't make some money out of it.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: But how can you be so sure? The Kid could do it, we both know that, but --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: "Could" isn't good enough for a man who hates to lose money as much as I do. He's going to need help -- from the best man with a pack of cards between Omaha and New Orleans.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Not a chance, Bill. You ought to know I never ever use what I got with the cards for nothing but tricks and dressing up a game.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Sure, I know it. That's why you're the man they choose to give them a square deal. That's what makes it so perfect. Nobody'll be looking for it.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: It's out. Out.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The great thing is they'll be so close, The Kid won't need much. Three or four key hands.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Understand this, Bill. I'd like for The Kid to win, and I sure as hell don't want to see you lose all that money --

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: If I did, I'd have to collect that twelve grand you owe me. Not myself. My collection agents. You knew poor Wildwood Jones, didn't you?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: OK but I'm paying it off! It's comin' in ain't it? Six grand already.  Bill, you got to listen to me --!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: No, I don't. It's quite the other way around. You have some delusion you're a free agent, but you're not. I own you.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: For God's sake --!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Shut up. I'll cross the twelve off the books and give you ten thousand dollars in cash. And you can tell The Kid if he needs more of a stake, I'll put it up.  Marvelous. Here's Rosanna with what you need.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: -- for that dry feeling on the roof of your mouth.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Shine them up for you sir?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: No, thanks.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Fetch you a newspaper maybe?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: How about a singy-song then? I play good.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Play what?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Dry corn in this one. Blue shale stone from the river in this one. You ready?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yes, I'm ready.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: You ready?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Hell, I'm ready for anything.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thank you very much. That was nice. Where did you learn to do that?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I picked it up from Herman.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Who is Herman?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: My friend I pick it up from.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Is he a good friend?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I don't know 'bout that suh. He just a frien' who teach me some things.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Well, I don't want a shine, but here's fifteen cents.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: And here's another dime for you, fella.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Nice little colored kid.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: -- Yeah.

Speaker: jansen
Dialogue: Monday night, uh, Kid?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Monday night.

Speaker: jansen
Dialogue: I sprung for some of the action. A yard and a half of that five-to-two.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thanks, Jansen.  Hey!

Speaker: jansen
Dialogue: We got to get you loosened up. I never felt you this tight.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Just tell The Shooter I'll be there on the dot Monday night.

Speaker: melba's voice
Dialogue: And until then?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: He doesn't have to know.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I'm not asking for him.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Hello, Kid.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Can I help you with those?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Taking if off is harder than taking it on in.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: How's The Shooter?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: You haven't played yet?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Monday.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: This is Eric, Mama. He's come to see me.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: We lost suction on the pump right in the middle of canning.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Spring beans, you have to cook them fast. But you find yourself some breakfast.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'm all right. Bus stopped for doughnuts and coffee.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: You can stay with us tonight and still make it back to St. Lou on the Sunday schedule by about midnight. I told Mama and Papa about The Man. And all.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Where is Mr. Craigie?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I think I will. I think I'd like that.  Okay?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Sure. And I'll see you a little later on.  Papa don't know everything. About you and me.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: How do you do, Mr. Craigie. I'm Eric Stoner.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Christian's Eric.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You seen her?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: She's helping her mother can.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You minding to marry Christian?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You got any objections if I do, or if I don't?

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Son, that's what I call a sharp answer.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: It was what I call a sharp question.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: We don't know much about you, Christian's mother and me.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'm what's known as a three-river man. Which just means I go around playing stud poker wherever I can find the kind of action I'm looking for.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You met Christian when she was working to Hot Springs?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yeah. I was playing in this game in the hotel and she was a waitress in the coffee shop. We went out. I told her I thought she could get a better job in St. Louis.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Now how did you happen to tell her that? Maybe you run some kind of employment service on the side?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I said it because I wanted her in St. Louis. Anyway, she made it there and she called me and we been seeing each other ever since.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Living together?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yeah, living together.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: How come she come home now? She going to have a baby?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Not that I know of.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You two have a fight?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: She must have had a reason.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Think so? Well, you've known her longer than me.  Look, Mr. Craigie, let me and Christian find out a few things then maybe I won't have to answer your questions.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: I never run across anybody like you. I guess I don't understand gamblers.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That's all right. I don't understand farmers.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You say things that sound smart alecky. But I'm not sure if they really are smart alecky.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Well I can't take into account what somebody's going to feel every time I say something.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Are you a believer?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: In some things.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: I mean in God.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That's a tough one. I don't disbelieve in Him, but I couldn't say I believed in Him either. I guess I just never paid Him much mind. Didn't seem important.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: God not important?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I don't mean what He does isn't important -- if He exists. I mean it's not important to me whether He exists or not.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Christian was raised in a Christian home.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Is that so? I didn't know ---  I'm not asking permission to marry Christian, you know.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: If I was, the only person I'd be asking it from is her.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Who is this fella Christian says you're going to play that's so important?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: He's the king of the stud poker players.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: And you're going to play him.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Are you any good?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'm this good. The Man has got to play me.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: What happens if he don't?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Then I'm The Man.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: That important to you?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I been trying to figure that out ever since I set it up.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You playing because of money?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Christian said you never was much worried about money -- I been worried about money most of my life -- up until I figured out it wasn't so important.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: No, it's necessary, but it isn't so important.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Well how come you want to play this King fella?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Ambition -- maybe security, like that.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Is it aspiration to be the King or just uncertainty about the future?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I ain't looking for security if that's what you mean.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Not trying to lock something up tight and nail it down?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That would figure into it. But that isn't all of it. -- It's important to me.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Now son which is more important to you, this king business or Christian?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: If you got the guts to ask that question, Mr. Craigie, I guess I got the guts to answer it. Christian, if you came right down to it, is not as important as doing what I have to do.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Well son, I had to know.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Know what?

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: There never was a man worth a damn, to my mind, who let his woman stand in the way of the thing he had to do.  I got to go now -- see what I can do for a sick heifer. Why don't you take Christian, when her Mama lets go of her, and tell her I said you should go to the old spring. It's a good place.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thanks. I'll tell her.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: It stays warm all winter.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Papa's mama used to bring her wash up here.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: We liable to draw an audience?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Don't worry. It's on our land -- Nobody uses it.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: You must have said something to Papa gave him the picture on us in St. Lou. Else he never would have spoke to you about this place.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I told him on account of he already knew. Never any sense feeding a man a lie he's not going to believe.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Even if he did know, I'm glad you told him.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Hey, you're all wet!

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: So are you, foolish.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Let me get this straight in my head. Cards is all a matter of luck, who gets dealt the best ones.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: So when one of you professional gamblers sits down with a bunch of your -- what do you call them -- customers, clients?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: The technical term is "suckers." Or "marks."

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Their chance of winning is just as good as yours, except if you got a way to control it, who gets what cards. Right?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Not right. That's cheating and it's not any part of what we're talking about.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Then how do you win?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'll show you.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You see one of these cards is white on both sides, one is red on both sides, and the other is white on one side, red on the other.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: This. I put the three cards in a hat and shake them up, and then I ask you to draw one card out blind. Put it face down on the table so neither of us can see the bottom side.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Okay, red on top. That eliminates the all-white card, right. So the card you've picked is one of two -- the all-red or the red-and-white. One out of two is an even chance, an even-money proposition. Right -- you follow me?

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: So if I said I'll bet you a dollar to seventy-five cents the other side of that card is red, you'd take the bet wouldn't you?

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Seems like. Yeah.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: And that answer makes you a sucker. Because the odds are two to one, the other side of that card is red, and I ought to be offering you a dollar to fifty cents instead of seventy- five.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: But if there are just the two possibilities.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: There are three possibilities.  That can be the red side of the red- and-white card, or it can be either side of the all-red card. In two cases out of three the other side is red. And I'd win the bet from you two out of every three times we made it.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: You would?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Sure. It's obvious when I explain it, isn't it?

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Reckon so. Except if there's only two things that the bottom side can be, red or white --

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Take my word for it -- the odds are two to one. And knowing that is the difference between your gambling man and your sucker. Not who gets the better cards but who knows what the proper odds are. In a poker game there can be a million different situations, each with a different set of odds to figure. The man who ends up winners is the man who knows when to bet and how much...

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: The sucker is still took advantage of, isn't he? The gambler knows something he don't know.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Sure -- like if you grow better corn or raise a cow that gives more milk than the other guy's. Or two business men are in competition, or two lawyers are up against each other in a courtroom. Whatever your line is, the one who wins out is the one who knows his job better.

Speaker: craigie
Dialogue: Seems like there should be something else to it --

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: There is -- Making the man you're playing against think he's got the best hand -- and making him pay to find out.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I can't stay long. Papa'll be getting up to milk.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'm the one can't stay. I got to head for that bus.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Why did you come, Kid?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Well, hell, I don't know. I had kind of a rough time after you left.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Rough how?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Tuesday there was a ball game, but then the Cardinals went on the road. I never known time to drag so; I was all torn apart --

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Because of the poker game coming up?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That's how I read it, but I was reading it wrong. It wasn't Lancey or the game that was chewing at my insides --

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: What else is there could give you such a bad time?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I finally figured it. I located where the trouble was. It was you.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Oh, --

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: When you talk about doing something besides poker if I get to be The Man, you don't mean pass up the chance to make some dough from it for a while?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I sure don't. I told Papa, wherever money comes from, it feels the same when you spend it.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You were going to do some thinking down here.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I done some.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'll be back after the game Christian -- You wait here for me and I'll let you know.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: All right Eric -- Good luck Monday.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I got that made now. You said it right. My time's come.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Twenty-five years I been building a reputation.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Handle this thing right and your reputation will be better than ever.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I made up my mind to this. I ain't going to give him any help till he needs it.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I'm glad you're taking a stand.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Hey, what if he starts off lucky and stays ahead of the game the whole way. It could happen, you know.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: You'll make it happen, Baby. I've got faith in you --

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Once more around the square.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: It's a friendly town, St. Louis. I've always said that.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: We ain't seen much of you though, last seven, eight years.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Climate, Shooter. In my declining years, I spend more and more time in Florida and the Gulf Coast.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Lot of folks been figuring another reason you was keeping clear of the three rivers.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: What reason is that, Lady Fingers?

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Cincinnati Kid.  That the way it is, Lancey? You been scared of The Kid?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Should I be scared of him?

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Damn right you should! I'm telling you, that boy going to make your stomach ulcer bleed before the night is out. He's close to murder. I seen him give a fella the shakes so bad on a fourth card, it took a pint of corn liquor to settle him down.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Thanks for the warning.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Mow the man down, sugar pie, make it quick and bloody. Been too many lean years for all of us.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I intend to take Shooter right along with Lancey.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I'm not talking about the old Shooter. He's been factory rebuilt. A new spirit dwelleth in him, and his gaze is on distant hills.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: So you showed up after all. You're a braver boy than I thought, so much the worse for you.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You think I'll be sorry I come?

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Bound to. That Lancey ain't human, he's one of them barracuda fish. He's liable to bleed to death, right on a flush hand before he give up to you. I seen him gut a fella so bad, the fella quit and got up and spit red in the john and went square.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Hello, Kid. Pleasure to know you.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Lancey. I been looking forward a long time.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure. You seem to know about everybody. Yeller from New Orleans?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: What do you say, Yeller? Still feeling salty with me?

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: Forgiven long since.  We had a little jurisdictional dispute.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I hustled a couple of boys, right in his territory.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: So I tried to tell him our rules down there. Colored marks are for colored hustlers.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: And I tried to tell him how I got no prejudice. When I'm on the edge of my stake, I hustle anybody at all, regardless of race, creed or color. Anybody at all.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: Including my girl.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Hell, I figured I was doin' you a favor.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Did you know Old Cottonhead died?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No, I hadn't heard.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Heart give out in a high-low game.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: How you feel, Kid?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Great. You?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: The best. You think maybe we ought to see if we can stir up some action?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Whatever you say, Lancey. You're the --  You're our guest in this town.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Well, I'm kind of in the mood to play a little cards.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I think we ought to be able to get a game together in this crowd.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: But first you take a look at things -- make sure everything's the way you want it. I already been around.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thanks. I'll do that.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: It's an old table. Everything's pretty old in this hotel.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: It's solid, that's what counts. And you got the top fixed perfect.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Light all right for you?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Two hundred watt bulb.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Fine, excellent. Okay with you?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure. Shooter's set us up just great.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Sure has.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Thank you, gents. Tried to do the best I could.  Cards?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Good a time as any.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You both know Joe Hoban. He's a draw poker man, but clean and straight as they come.

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: They come from the St. Louis Bridge Club, but they're poker size cards. They been bonded by the club steward and I seen him take them out of the safe. Shooter, Lady Fingers and me pick them up and come straight here with them.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Hoban's selling them to us at five dollars a pack, with the usual guarantee. If it's proved any deck is spooked, he pays off the losers.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: St. Louis Bridge Club, eh? Steward still that old yard bird Okra?

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: That's him.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Old stud man, Okra.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I don't know him.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Quite a character. Quite a character.

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Nobody heard from me what the cards were for, Kid.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Been ten years since I seen or spoke to Old Okra.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: 'Kay, fine. Don't worry about it, Lancey. Who's sitting down with us, Shooter?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Four of us. Me, Pig, Yeller and Doc Sokal. If that's all right with you both?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: 'Kay, fine.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure.  Shall we have a look at the decks?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Well, Kid, what's your game?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I don't mind stud poker if that's okay with you.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: I got no objections to stud.  Gentlemen?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Tell The Kid I have a suite on the fifth floor. He can drop up during the breaks. Bedroom all for him any time he wants a nap.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: That's thoughtful of you, Bill.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I'm a thoughtful man. I hope you are.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Privilege of age. Can't take the glare of the morning sun in my eyes.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You want to have the usual brandy and coffee on hand, Kid? Anything special for you, Lancey?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Why, yes, Shooter. Creme de menthe frappe. Green.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Gentlemen, if there are no objections, I'm the dealer. These rooms have been contracted for, and there will be an ante of ten dollars per chair, per day. During the breaks for me, Old Lady Fingers has agreed to deal, but she don't care to be a player --

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Can't afford to play, that's the real truth. Had a bad year and I'm way over my edge.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Lady Fingers will get three dollars an hour from the ante, plus her room and food, and a five-minute break every hour. Gents?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Fine, Shooter man.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: 'Kay with us.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: If you don't see me when you need me, call room three-oh-eight.  You know who else ain't with us no more? Miriam, widow used to run the kitchen game to South Chi. Lost two month's Relief at blackjack, coal dealer cut her credit, and she froze in her bed.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Gentlemen, this is a game of five- card stud poker. There is no limit. A dead man has one half hour to raise his roll outside and get back in the game.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Five grand? Nice, tidy sum. I'll put out the same.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: I swear I don't know what I'm doing sitting down with you titans, but maybe it's worth putting up five thousand for the educational value.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: I'll play with what I have in my pocket till I have to send out for more. Twenty-seven, twenty-eight hundred, I don't know.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Five G's, I'm with it. Don't mean I'm goin' blow it all, though.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Last and certainly least --

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Seven, nine, trey, nine, ace, and The Shooter guns up a ten. Ace bets.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Ten dollars.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Dealer folds.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Call the sawbuck.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'm in.

Speaker: pig's voice
Dialogue: Call.

Speaker: yeller's voice
Dialogue: Call.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: King to the seven, pair of nines, deuce to the trey, queen-nine, ace- eight.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Nines bet twenty bucks.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Queen, ten, king, four, ace again, and a king for The Shooter.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Ace bets ten dollars

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: King over.

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Shooter won't stay on a king or an ace if there's another one showing.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's he have to have in the hole?

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Ten or better. With no other ten showing.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: New deck.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: Aces over eights.  Be a laugh if the two champs ended up cleaned.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Any action?

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: What do you expect first five or six hours?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Still feeling each other out?

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Pig's ahead about a grand, Shooter maybe three hundred.

Speaker: shooter's voice
Dialogue: King bets.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: King says twenty.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: In for twenty.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: To the nine a ten, to the queen a seven, to the king a jack, and to the jack a jack.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Pair of jacks will venture a hundred dollars.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: I'm in.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: Up two hundred dollars.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: Leave it to the rich folk.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Lancey could be laying for him with three jacks.

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Pig don't think so.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: I'm sticking.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Possible straight flush, pair of sevens. Pair of jacks are still high.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Check to the sevens.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Likewise.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: Bet the size of the pot. Nine hundred and eighty dollars.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: In for nine eighty.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: I'll play.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What's with Lancey? I thought he'd raise with three jacks or drop with two pair.

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: He probably thinks Pig's faking the queens. Anyhow, Doc's liable take them both with a straight or a flush.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Busted, no flush, no straight. Pair of sevens with a queen gets a nine. To the pair of jacks, a trey.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: Pair of sevens will bet whatever I got here. Twenty-four hundred bucks.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: I'll call your twenty-four hundred --

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Comes to fourteen hundred fifty dollars, Pig. Don't imagine you'll have any problem promoting that much in half an hour -- plus whatever you care to raise me.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Fourteen fifty to the queens. You want to take your half hour, Pig?

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: No, I'm out. Out of the game.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You Tap City?

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: I got a woman.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I thought you and Hilda were quits.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: We're back.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: See you around, Pig.

Speaker: players
Dialogue: So long, Pig -- See you -- 'Night.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: So long.

Speaker: pig
Dialogue: Good luck -- Kid.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: He shouldn't have said that. Not after taking Tap City from the table.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: His woman's been giving him a rough time. Wants him to quit and go square.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: At his age? Crazy.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: He wants to wish anybody luck, doesn't bother me. Personally, I don't figure The Kid needs it.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Thanks, Lancey.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I know it's early, men, but what about taking a little break?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: It always distresses me, a man reaching his middle years and still having no assurance of next week's income.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I know what you mean. I like a man to have plenty of assurance.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Spider Man died kind of slow. First he give them a kidney, then his gall bladder, and then they taking his whole damn stomach. You remember Spider Man, run the dice table down at Turk's Club to Memphis.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Who? Oh, Spider Man, sure, sure.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: He died kind of slow.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Need your help, Lady Fingers... to make arrangements for food and shelter.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Good crowd.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yeah. Nice-looking broads.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: That's a fact.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That was a pretty thing to watch what you done to Pig with those jacks.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Thanks, Kid. From you, that's nice to hear.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: When he bet out first, he was ready to think you had them back to back. Even when he bet the size of the pot, he figured there was still a chance you were laying for him. But when you called him, I could see it in his eyes he thought you had jacks and tens, and I knew you had him hooked.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: You knew, did you? Before I raised?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Oh, sure, I seen what you were pulling all along.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: You been to Miami, Kid?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Beautiful town, lot of loose money around. You ought to come down some time.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: You mean it?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure. Lot of room down there. Another spot you ought to work someday is Reno, Nevada.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I heard.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: You got to have nerves though. So much going on. Action everywhere you turn. You lose the feel of the cards when you're in so much action day in, day out.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I'd like to make it out there.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: There's different levels of action there -- you'd find yours, any kind you could ask for.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I generally stick to stud.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Sure, sure, for eating money. But you know how it is, I like to lay off once in a while and try craps. Nothing serious -- I don't even think of it as work.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Oh, I do that. I'll take a night off and shoot a little casino. Or even blackjack.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Your age, you don't need a regular vacation every year. But me, I have to forget the grind for a couple of weeks. I go to this place near Delray Beach, and the whole time I don't play anything but bridge.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That's interesting. I could go for bridge if there was a way to do it without partners.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: I'm not keeping you from your woman, am I?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: No. We're -- she's gone away for a while. We're not sure we're looking for the same thing.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: I'm sorry to hear that.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I was hoping Christian would run with me and wouldn't try to make a big deal out of it.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: But she tried?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yeah, and now I don't know. I don't figure a man can change his way because the way I see it a man's lucky he's got something going for him that he can hold on to. A man can't change his way for a woman.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Nooo, a man can't do that.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: I been wondering if it isn't maybe a better idea not to look for a fixed thing. Just tie in to something nice when you're away from the action, and enjoy it, and let it wear itself out.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: That's very interesting you should say that. You're pretty young to have figured things out already.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Well she didn't understand how it was with me and ---

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Between us?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: There ain't but a few people, I guess who would understand --

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Kid, you're the best stud man I've seen in 35 years of action. You know that?

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Well -- thank you.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: And when it comes to broads, which is getting to be an academic problem -- I can look back now to the two or three I ever considered I might want to spend the rest of my life with, and you know what? I like it... looking back on them, that is --  I always got a lot of companionship out of a good book.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: It's very educational, hearing what it's like for a man your age.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Glad to be of help. And it's good we had this little talk so I know we can be friends regardless what happens.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: That sounds good to me. I didn't think you was coming in at me like a grudge match.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No room for any kind of emotion in a fair game of stud. I learned that a long time ago.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: It's a whole New Deal. Good hands all around. Prosperity for everybody.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: You're still good, Fingers.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Getting crippled up, Lancey. Not many of the old gang left. You heard Whistling Sam was gone?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No, I didn't hear.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: I was the one got called to the morgue to identify him. I don't suppose you seen anybody been run over by a twelve- ton bulldozer.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No, can't say that I have.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Don't go out of your way.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Bet the pot. Four hundred and twenty dollars.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Fold.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: It's yours.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Thanks, gents. Makes me exactly even. This kind of a game, that's a smart place to quit.  Just do the dealing, if that's all right with everybody.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Ace-king is the high man.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Shoot the works.  Nine hundred and thirty bucks.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: I'm over.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: What have you got?

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Doesn't matter. If you can call me, you beat me. Ace-king high.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Ace-king-queen high.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: I had them both with a pair of fives.

Speaker: sokal
Dialogue: Winds it up for me, men. And I can't say it's been a pleasure.  That one I was sure I could steal.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: Lancey has a built-in burglar alarm. I'm also withdrawing from the field of battle, gentlemen. Settle for the seventeen hundred I've already dropped.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Well, just the two of us.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Yeah, just the two of us. Deal them, Shooter Man.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Cost you a grand.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Compulsory call, Kid.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Two pair, jacks up.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Kings up.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Two thousand dollars.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Call two thousand.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: Take it. I can't beat three sevens.  I'd like a break to get some food and sleep -- I'm winners so it isn't up to me to say it but I'm saying it anyway.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: My dear, that young man is a stud poker-playing son-of-a-bitch.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: Gettin' to you, Lancey?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Not yet he isn't.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Now, just what the hell are you trying to pull?

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Nothing -- what are you talking about?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You, Shooter Man -- you been feeding me cards for an hour.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Christ, Kid, even if I was you couldn't spot it -- I'm too good a mechanic for anybody to spot it.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: But I was looking for it, Shooter -- four times you give me the cards I need.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You seen it before often enough. One player draws four good ones.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Never in a game when I been told ahead the dealer has a stake in my coming out on top.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: My woman told you.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: She told me enough to make me start thinking.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Why should you bitch if I give you a little help?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Why, you dumb bastard? -- You have to ask me why.  I could break you apart for what you've done.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Kid, you got to understand. It wasn't my idea --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Well who the hell's was it then -- Schlaegel? --

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: He's got the squeeze on me Kid and he's meaner than hell. He'll cut me up if I don't come through.  You think I wanted to deal a phony game? You think it don't mean something to me? I never done a crooked thing before in my life.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: My ass bleeds for you -- Now you get straight on this. No fix. You come along straight or I blow it wide open.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: He's liable to kill me.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: He ain't goin' to do nothin' to you except pay off because I'm goin' to win.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: It is a hell of a chance to take.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You got no choice.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: He ain't goin' to like it.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Shooter, I'm goin' to win this one -- win it my way -- and you ride with me or you're out, finished.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: I ride with you.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You better not forget it -- now beat it. I need some sleep.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Tell Mr. Schlaegel I accept his offer to use the room.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I want to be called at 4 p.m. on the nose. For sure -- Thanks.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Not yet he isn't. But he damn well might.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Good afternoon, sir. It's exactly four o'clock.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: It's really only about twenty-five to four. You can stay right where you are.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I don't want you to think I'm getting too personal, but you mind telling me how the hell you come to be here?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: You mean you don't remember last night? We drank all that champagne and you said "Let's get married right away," and we chartered a plane to --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Can it --  Where's Shooter?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I locked the door. It's incredible the way you invariably worry about The Shooter.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: It's incredible the way you invariably don't.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Worrying takes time and we don't have a lot.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: We're supposed to sit down again at half past four.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Does it really matter so much to you now, that sense of obligation to The Shooter?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Or to you.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Obligations are not what I have in mind.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Reach me a towel?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: You any idea how much The Shooter has involved in this game of yours?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: If Schlaegel bet as much on me as I heard, I guess he'd pay a nice piece of change to be sure I won.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: It's worse than that. Schlaegel staked him for three years. He has his hooks so deep in Shooter Man, he'll take out his liver when he pulls them out.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You asking me to go along with the fix?

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: I'm asking you to consider whether your ego is worth destroying another man's whole life.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You're still working for him. On my time you're still working for him.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: What kind of switch is this? You criticize me for trying to chippie on him, then I get a little loyal and you're at me for that.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: No -- I don't hold it against you. You wanting to make things right for him -- but this game I handle my way -- win, lose, or draw.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Rolls and coffee for the hard-headed hero.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Believe me Kid there is too much at stake for us to rely on your doing it on your own.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Hello, Kid. Hello, Melba.  You said wait home 'til you let me know.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Yeah, that's what I said. We took a break in the game to catch some sleep. Shooter sent his woman up here to wake me up.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Yeah, I woke him up.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: It don't take much.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: No, I didn't find it any trouble.  You, too, honey, right?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I'll be around if The Kid wants me.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: See you, Melba. Thanks.

Speaker: melba
Dialogue: Por nada, as they say. It was nothing.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You been to the place?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: No, I've got my bag downstairs. Maybe I'll take it over later on tonight.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: How's your Mama and Papa?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Fine. How's the game going?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: It's come to be just me and Lancey.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I was wondering.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I got my mind on the cards.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I know. And I don't want to rattle you. We got plenty to talk about, but it can all wait. Except I want to say this. I came back because I figured if it was going to work with us, it's silly me sitting home with Mama while you're playing your big game. I mean if I'm any use to you at all, this is when it's most important.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I'm glad you came, Christian. You got as much right here as anybody.  More right, I should have said.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Should you?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Hell, yes. The change I come out with when I win this one, you're going to be the one to spend it.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Eric --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Look, I said I'm glad you came -- and that's all until I wrap this up -- I'm a poker player, remember?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: The eight'll try two bills.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No stay.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Two hundred.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: No stay.

Speaker: yeller
Dialogue: Anything?

Speaker: hoban
Dialogue: Naaa, Kid paired kings. He wins a hundred.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Queen bets another C-note.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Take it away.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Go read a magazine, honey.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: I break.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I don't want a break.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Well, I don't either.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Deal.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Same deck is good enough.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I want a new deck.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Alright, alright -- A new deck then, Jesus.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Deal.

Speaker: lady fingers
Dialogue: You want to deal? Then deal them yourselves. I'm going to the john. I'm going to get something to eat, and I'm going to take a nap. You barracudas can snap all you want but at each other -- I'm taking a break and if you don't like it you can both go to hell.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I guess we been told.

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Looks that way.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: See you in about 3/4 of an hour, Lancey, right?

Speaker: lancey
Dialogue: Make it an hour. Old bones need a little more time to loosen up.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Listen, I think it is amazing you've been able to keep going this long.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Eric --

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: Your fan on the fifth floor wants you to have a bite with him. Alone.

Speaker: kid
Dialogue: There's nothing to talk about.

Speaker: shooter
Dialogue: You better, Kid. You don't, you're only making worse trouble.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: If you think so.  Sorry.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Nothing, Nothing you have to worry about. I'll see you later.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Get something to eat.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I thought it would be better if you and I sat down together to see if we couldn't work out our differences. Felix!

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What I told The Shooter goes.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Are you saying no before we've even discussed it? Am I to feel all my arguments will be wasted?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I'll skip to the final argument.  More salad, perhaps?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: The Shooter will be back dealing when you start again. He will give you an occasional helpful card.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: That's an argument?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: That's a fact. I'm coming to the argument.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I'll give you a fact. I won't let it happen.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Is that knife sharp enough? Felix.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: See if it cuts better with that.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Sharp?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Very. But it don't cut any ice with me.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Not this time. He exits.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Did you eat?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Why not, for Chris sakes?

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: Eric --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You should eat something.

Speaker: christian
Dialogue: I've got to talk to you.

Speaker: the kid
